text: Don't Eat Meat Today: A Simple Step with Profound Impact
The choices we make daily, especially about food, have a ripple effect on our planet. One of the most straightforward yet profoundly impactful decisions? Skipping meat for just one day.

Producing meat, especially beef, has a hefty environmental toll. For instance, producing just one kilogram of beef requires about 15,000 liters of water¹ and emits 27 kg of CO2². Chicken, though less resource-intensive than beef, still requires 3,900 liters of water for one kilogram³ and emits 6.9 kg of CO2⁴.

In contrast, a plant-based meal is significantly more eco-friendly. For example, producing a kilogram of tomatoes requires only 180 liters of water⁵ and emits a mere 0.9 kg of CO2⁶. By choosing a plant-based meal over a beef meal, you can save around 25 kg of CO2 and 14,415 liters of water in just one meal! Opting for plants over chicken? You're still saving 6 kg of CO2 and 3,720 liters of water.

To put things in perspective, the average person in the US has a carbon footprint of about 16 tons annually, which breaks down to roughly 44 kg per day⁷. Globally, the average is around 4 tons annually or about 11 kg daily⁸. By choosing a plant-based meal, you're making a dent in your daily carbon footprint.
So, the next time you're planning a meal, consider the broader impact of your choices. A simple shift towards more plant-based options can make a significant difference for our planet.
